Class DependencyGraph

  • java.lang.Object
    • DependencyGraph

  • public class DependencyGraph
extends java.lang.Object
    Author:
    Lennart Schmeling (initial version), Katja KÃ¶nig (conjunction normalization, stringify) An instance of the class DependencyGraph represents an instance of the dependency graph structure of a sentence. All dependency graphs have a WordObj root as their uppermost node. Then they consist of a HashSet in which all the graph's edges are stored (existing dependency relations between WordObj). Also, all the nodes of the graph are stored in a separate HashSet.

      check if there are two linked edges in the graph where the dependency label of 1st edge is either objp or pp and the 2nd one is a pn - this is important to normalize prepositional phrases two for-loops needed because there are seldom occurrences of objp/pp only, those should not be considered

      check if graph has edges which call for one of the normalization methods (for preposition phrases / predicative adjectives / auxillary verbs) while-loop forces the method to run until all the normalizations have taken place (often more than one per sentence)
      DependencyGraph normalizeActivePassive(DependencyGraph graph)
      normalize dependency relations for passive forms: swap dependency relations for subj and obja/objp-von/objp-vom Example: "Der Kuchen wurde von Jan geliebt" - "der Kuchen" must be target and therefore changed to an obja-relation (although it is the sentence's subject) "von Jan" is source and its dependency relation must change from objp-von to subj

           WordObj target,
           java.lang.String depRel)
        add an edge to the Hashset edges of a graph object
        Parameters:
        source - the node where the edge starts
        target - the node where the edge terminates
        depRel - the dependency label which should be annotated for this edge
        Returns:
        the newly added edge

                java.lang.String depRel)
        Parameters:
        target - A node in the graph which is supposed to have an incoming edge with a certain label
        depRel - the dependency relation of this edge
        Returns:
        True if edge exists, False otherwise

        public WordObj getParent(WordObj target,
                java.lang.String depRel)
        Return a node who is starting point for an edge with a specified dependency relation to a certain child node
        Parameters:
        target - the node to which an edge with a dependency label should point
        depRel - the dependency relation for this edge
        Returns:
        the parent node if it has an edge in the graph to the child with the dependency relation

        depRel - the dependency relation
        Returns:

        Returns:

      • hasTargetRelation

        public boolean hasTargetRelation(WordObj target,
                        java.lang.String depRel)
        check if there is a node in graph which has an incoming edge with a specified dependency relation
        Parameters:
        target - The node whose incoming edges should be examined
        depRel - The dependency relation, annotated on an edge pointing on this node
        Returns:
        true if relation exists, false otherwise

      • hasObjpPpToPnRelation

        public boolean hasObjpPpToPnRelation(WordObj source,
                            java.lang.String depRel)
        check if there are two linked edges in the graph where the dependency label of 1st edge is either objp or pp and the 2nd one is a pn - this is important to normalize prepositional phrases two for-loops needed because there are seldom occurrences of objp/pp only, those should not be considered
        Parameters:
        source - WordObj which is supposed to be the parent node of the preposition
        depRel - either objp or pp
        Returns:
        true if prepositional phrase exists, no otherwise

      • getPnFromObjpPpToPnRelation

        public WordObj getPnFromObjpPpToPnRelation(WordObj source,
                                  java.lang.String depRel)
        Given the node in a graph which is starting point for a objp/pp + pn relation (2 edges in a row, indicating a PP), return the node which is ending point of this extended relation. This is normally the WordObj which is at the same time the head of the noun phrase in the prepositional phrase.
        Parameters:
        source - the WordObj from which the prepositional relation starts
        depRel - depending if the prepositional phrase is complement or adjunct, either objp or pp
        Returns:
        the node in the graph to which the objp/pp + pn- Relation points

      • getSentimentSourceTarget

        public java.util.ArrayList<WordObj> getSentimentSourceTarget(WordObj sentiment,
                                                    java.lang.String label,
                                                    WordObj containsDeleted)
        This method returns either the corresponding source or the target (depending if it has been called to identify source or target in SentimentChecker class) for a given sentiment expression.
        Parameters:
        sentiment - The sentiment expression the graph contains (WordObj is entry in the sentiment lexicon)
        label - It should be checked whether the sentiment expression has an outgoing node to another node (this would then be the source or the target) with a certain dependency relation specified in this parameter
        containsDeleted - If there is a sentiment expression whose corresponding node in the graph of the sentence has been deleted due to normalization, the WordObj parent node (which is still in the graph, necessary to yield existing graph relations) will be stored in this parameter (empty otherwise)
        Returns:
        a list in which the source or the target is stored, empty otherwise if no fitting source/target exists for given label and sent expr

      • getSentimentSourceTarget

        public java.util.ArrayList<WordObj> getSentimentSourceTarget(WordObj sentiment,
                                                    java.lang.String label)
        This method returns either the corresponding source or the target (depending if it has been called to identify source or target in SentimentChecker class) for a given sentiment expression.
        Parameters:
        sentiment - The sentiment expression the graph contains (WordObj is entry in the sentiment lexicon)
        label - It should be checked whether the sentiment expression has an outgoing node to another node (this would then be the source or the target) with a certain dependency relation specified in this parameter
        Returns:
        a list in which the source or the target is stored, empty otherwise if no fitting source/target exists for given label and sent expr

      • checkPassive

        public boolean checkPassive(WordObj source)
        if participle contains the lemma "werden" in deletedWords (after aux-Normalization), we encountered a passive sentence in which normalization of dependency labels is needed. Attention: rule out Konjunktiv II-sentences in German by boolean "habenInside": in "Er wird gegessen haben" is no normalization needed although "werden" is contained
        Parameters:
        source - the source which is supposed to be the participle of a passive form (Partizip II in German)
        Returns:
        true if "haben" or "werden" in DeletedWords, false otherwise

      • correctPhrasalVerbs

        public void correctPhrasalVerbs(DependencyGraph graph)
        This method checks if there are phrasal verbs in a sentence (e.g. "auf|brauchen, ab|nehmen") if this is the case, the lemma entry in the WordObj class will be changed for the root of the verb (nehmen --> abnehmen etc.) if phrasal verbs are sentiment expressions, they will not be retrieved otherwise
        Parameters:
        graph - dependency graph as input

      • isNormalized

        public boolean isNormalized()
        check if graph is already normalized (no more edges with dependency labels pred, aux, pp and pn)
        Returns:
        True if this is the case, False otherwise

      • normalize

        public DependencyGraph normalize(DependencyGraph graph)
        check if graph has edges which call for one of the normalization methods (for preposition phrases / predicative adjectives / auxillary verbs) while-loop forces the method to run until all the normalizations have taken place (often more than one per sentence)
        Parameters:
        graph - the sentence's graph as input
        Returns:
        the normalized graph, or if no normalization needed, the same graph as the input

      • normalizePredVerb

        public DependencyGraph normalizePredVerb(WordObj word,
                                DependencyGraph graph)
        normalize auxillary verbs and predicative expressions and return an updated graph object
        Parameters:
        word - The WordObj of the auxillary verb or predicative expression respectively
        graph - The graph object of the sentence
        Returns:
        an updated graph object in with adjusted nodes and edges

      • normalizeObjpPP

        public DependencyGraph normalizeObjpPP(WordObj word,
                              DependencyGraph graph,
                              java.lang.String depRel)
        normalize prepositional phrases and return an updated graph object
        Parameters:
        word - the WordObj in the graph from which the prepositional phrase's edges leave
        graph - the sentence's graph object
        depRel - specify if the prepositional phrase is either introduced by a pp- oder an objp-relation
        Returns:
        the normalized graph object

      • normalizeActivePassive

        public DependencyGraph normalizeActivePassive(DependencyGraph graph)
        normalize dependency relations for passive forms: swap dependency relations for subj and obja/objp-von/objp-vom Example: "Der Kuchen wurde von Jan geliebt" - "der Kuchen" must be target and therefore changed to an obja-relation (although it is the sentence's subject) "von Jan" is source and its dependency relation must change from objp-von to subj
        Parameters:
        graph - the sentence's graph as input
        Returns:
        the updated dependency graph with new relations (if necessary)

      • normalizeConjunctions

        public DependencyGraph normalizeConjunctions(DependencyGraph graph)
        Normalizes the given graph by taking conjunctions into account. In particular, it adds relational edges to the conjuncts such that all of them are related as the first conjunct (only within "a single" (conceived) conjunction). For this only the 'subj', 'attr' and 'obja' relations are considered depending on the POS-tags of the conjuncts and whether or not the sentence was normalized due to active and passive voice. These additional edges enable later steps to find opinion sources or targets more reliably (frame construction).
        Parameters:
        graph - The graph to be normalized.
        Returns:
        the normalized graph.

      • getMweMatches

        public java.util.ArrayList<WordObj> getMweMatches(WordObj startNode,
                                         java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> mweWordsToBeMatched,
                                         boolean topCall)
        Returns the list of WordObj nodes from the that are matched with the mweWordsToBeMatched in lemma or name, and are chained with the startNode (recursive function).
        Parameters:
        startNode - the node from which the chain search starts.
        mweWordsToBeMatched - is the list of strings/words that are to be found/matched in the graph/tree.
        topCall - indicates if it is the top call of the recursive function or not.
        Returns:
        the list of connected WordObj nodes that are matched with the mweWordsToBeMatched.

      • getSentimentSourceTargetMWE

        public java.util.ArrayList<WordObj> getSentimentSourceTargetMWE(WordObj wtmp,
                                                       SentimentUnit mwe,
                                                       java.lang.String label,
                                                       WordObj containsDeleted)
        This method is similar to getSentimentSourceTarget(WordObj, String, WordObj) except that it deals with multi-word expressions (MWEs). It returns either the corresponding source or the target (depending if it has been called to identify source or target in SentimentChecker class) for a given sentiment expression that is of the 'mwe' type.
        Parameters:
        wtmp - The word from which the MWE sentiment expression is recognized.
        mwe - The sentiment expression (mwe) that is matched.
        label - It should be checked whether the sentiment expression has an outgoing node to another node (this would then be the source or the target) with a certain dependency relation specified in this parameter
        containsDeleted - If there is a sentiment expression whose corresponding node in the graph of the sentence has been deleted due to normalization, the WordObj parent node (which is still in the graph, necessary to yield existing graph relations) will be stored in this parameter (empty otherwise)
        Returns:
        a list in which the source or the target is stored, empty otherwise if no fitting source/target exists for given label and sent expr

      • mweMatch

        public boolean mweMatch(WordObj wtmp,
               SentimentUnit mwe)
        This method returns if a multi-word expression (MWE) is matched on a particular word, ie. if the word is member of a connected subgraph of which the nodes match the words of the MWE.
        Parameters:
        wtmp - The word from which the MWE could be evoked (lexicon entry).
        mwe - The MWE that is checked.
        Returns:
        Boolean representing if the MWE is matched in the graph

      • removeDistantDuplicates

        public java.util.ArrayList<WordObj> removeDistantDuplicates(java.util.ArrayList<WordObj> matches,
                                                   int minLength)
        Removes from an array list of word objects those duplicates that lie farthest (position in sentence) from the other (non-duplicate) words, as long as the list does not become smaller than the minLength
        Parameters:
        matches - is the ArrayList from which duplicates are removed
        minLength - is the length that the matches should have at least. (So if there are still duplicates, but the minLength is reached nothing is removed)
        Returns:
        ArrayList

      • getDuplicates

        public java.util.ArrayList<WordObj> getDuplicates(java.util.ArrayList<WordObj> matches)
        Returns two duplicate words (WordObj) that are found in matches (not more than two!), if there are any duplicates.
        Parameters:
        matches - is the ArrayList in which two duplicates are searched for.
        Returns:
        ArrayList of the duplicates, if they are found.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object

      • stringifyEdges

        public java.lang.String stringifyEdges()
        Returns a string representation of all edges in the dependency graph. This is done by calling the 'toString' method of 'Edge'. Each edge has its own line in this representation.
        Returns:
        a string representation of all edges in the dependency graph.

      • stringifyWordList

        public java.lang.String stringifyWordList()
        Returns a string representation of all word objects in the word list. They are separated by a single space character.
        Returns:
        a string representation of all word objects in the word list.
